comments.commentBody: Binsar Bakkara is the top photojournalist

Buyers of Nero 10 software need to be aware of the fact that they may get a buggy product, as I did, and no real free technical support (they never pick up the phone). Be prepared for very frustrating and time-consuming interactions with them.
If you remember that paragraph is "^p", you don't need to copy and paste a paragraph mark or choose it from the Special menu. Just literally type "^p" (caret p).
I thought the people who make the LOJACK automobile theft systems are also offering a gps kind of service that people can use.  Have you checked it out?
I just need to know if anyone really believes in Papi's resurrection without drugs?

Congrats Sam!!!

Buh Bye Henin
Henin should go back into retirement.  She was not missed!!

I like the guy, and like his caustic wit, and drollery. His self-effacing comments after his last two losses to Federer were charming, and before he made his splash into the top ten two years ago, I still remember the US TV announcers and Tennis Ex-jocks like Gilbert and Mac hinting that he was a little different from the other players on the tour- which naturally makes me think they don't like him or his idiosyncrasies. (Which, when I think of it, makes me want to like him all the more!)

But Soderling can be brittle at times on the court- it was at Estoril I think when he bowed out pretty easily. I wish for him that he keeps his confidence and doesn't go away when things get tough.

He doesn't have anything to prove.  He's 23, has won 6 grand slam titles (including one each on grass and a hard court), has just set a record of Master's series titles, and is focused, healthy, and enjoying himself.  The press needs a story and some journalists have their axes to grind.  Yours is so patently anti-Nadal it doesn't need pointing out.  Roger had to face down the premature "it's over" noise a year ago; Nadal had to listen to it at the end of last year and the beginning of this.  They're savvy and experienced enough to look past the sensationalism:  their focus is their tennis, working hard, winning (and losing gracefully).  If Rafael fails to win this tournament I'd say he has at least two to three more French Open wins in him (plus another Wimbledon and another hard-court grand slam)--at least.  And the Federer-Nadal rivalry is the best thing that's happened to tennis since Sampras-Agassi and the Williams sisters.  Imagine the sport without either Federer or Nadal--Djokovic, Murray, del Potro, or Roddick able to sustain a rivalry of this quality, intensity, and character?  What a joke.
Great to see Maria playing better. She should have won this and probably would have if the matched had not been stopped and delayed until the next day.

Thanks for the excellent rundown of the match as I was only able to see the 3rd set. As a big Justine fan I was disappointed, but Stoser hung in there and was up to the challenge. I couldn't help but notice how many first serves Henin was missing and how vulnerable it made her as a result. In her first tournament back, the Australian, this was something I saw as a glaring problem that she needed to work on in order to make a strong comeback. As the stats prove, Stoser's 70% winning percentage on second serves made quite a difference. Once Henin gets her first serve consistent and stops making so many uncharacteristic unforced groundstroke errors she should be back to her old self. Her lack of backhand winners wasn't a good sign either. Stoser seems to have quite alot of talent with the big serve and forehand and can go far on the tour.

If you make a prediction often enough it is bound to come true.  Then you will look like a genius!  And everyone will forget the 100 times you were wrong.  Sure Soderling could win.  Don't bet the house on it.

Hard to believe that anyone brings exo results into real conversations about tennis.  Great example:  2007 Fed vs. Roddick in Koooyong, Fed vs. Roddick in Melbourne.  That being said, Soderling isn't afraid of Federer.  He's playing well, but 3 sets off Fed, when you've won something like 2 total in 12 tries, is a lot to ask for.

In Baltimore one sees trucks from John C. Flood plumbing contractors.
Google finds several Schock Electrical contractors.
The head of the Baltimore Zoo retired, and started a stuffed-animal store at HarborPlace called Embraceable Zoo. He was forced to change the name, though, by the copyright holder of a similar-sounding song.
No pun in the name, but there was a plant store in Baltimore located at the intersection of Light and Water streets.
There's also a beauty parlor called The Little Shop of Hair.

What about crossword klutzes? For example, crossword klutz, (noun) - A person, male or female, who is not very good at solving or completing crossword puzzles. Example: "Oh, I'm such a crossword klutz! I always start off full of grit and determination, but I always end up giving up before I can finish it. I was not born to be good at crossword puzzles, I guess."

-- overheard at a watercooler in Manhattan on April 7, 2010
by crosswordklutz101 on May 31, 2010
Nice post!

I've long wondered about the relationship between junior and senior Slam titles - after all, John McEnroe, Bjorn Borg, Mats Wilander, Justine Henin, Pat Cash, Roger Federer, etc all won at both levels.

So I finally sat down and manually compared the lists of junior and senior singles slam winners for boys and men. I may have made mistakes, so feel free to check this yourself:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_Men's_Singles_champions
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_Boys'_Singles_champions

This minor amateur analysis should be read with caution, especially if you're a young tennis player. For one thing, singles isn't everything. For another, slams aren't everything.

Of the 106 boys who've won junior singles slam titles since 1980, just 5 went on to win a senior title - Roddick (junior Oz 2000, jUS 00), Fed (jWim 98), Pat Cash (jWim 82), Mats Wilander (jFrench 81), and Stefan Edberg (the only person to win a junior Grand Slam, which he did in 1983).

Btw, all five men won senior titles within five years of their junior title, which is unwelcome news for a certain Scottish gent (jUS 04) and Gael Monfils (jOz 04, jFrench 04, jWim o4).

Of the boys who've won junior Slams since 1990, I count just 9 who have reached a senior Slam final so far - Fed, Andy R, Andy M, El Mago (Coria), Tsonga, Baghdatis, Gonzo, Nalbandian, and Ríos. Admittedly, one of their primary sins was to be born in the age of Fed & Rafa.

Speaking of Rafa, he never won a junior Slam - I think he only entered two junior tournaments, reaching the junior Wimbledon semis in 2002. He was knocked out by Lamine Ouahab, who went on to lose to Todd Reid in the final. Incidentally, in the girls final that year, one Maria Sharapova - who won the senior title two years later - lost to Vera Douchevina. Kim's little sister Elke (now retired due to injuries) was part of the junior doubles winning team that year (Barbora Strycova was her partner).
http://www.clgandjrtennis.com...

Of the 28 men who have won senior Slams since 1990, only 4 won junior Slams: Ivan Lendl (jFr 78, jWim 78), Edberg, Roddick, Fed.

In other words, 24 men who won senior Slams since 1990 did NOT do so at junior level: Gómez, Sampras, Becker, Courier, Stich, Agassi, Bruguera, Muster, Kafelnikov, Krajicek, Kuerten, Rafter, Korda, Moyá, Safin, Ivanišević, Hewitt, Johansson, Costa, Ferrero, El Gato (Gaudio), Nadal, Djoker, El Lobo (delpo).

For the women (I was too tired to repeat the whole process) : Venus, Serena, Kim, Maria, Kuzy, Pierce, Steffi, Arantxa, Monica, Majoli, Novotná, Ivanović, Myskina have no junior singles slams, but Justine, Mauresmo, Capriati, Hingis, and Davenport do.

Winning singles Slams isn't everything - what matters for young tennis players is enjoying the game and making a living from it. (And as a doubles fan, I'd also add playing doubles.) Any kid who reaches a Slam final and thinks "Oh no, I'm gonna jinx myself if I win this!" is a twit. Do your best - it's all that'll ever be asked from you.
Right on, Pepe! (Write on?)
Fun to learn Moe's last name. As with so many things on "The Simpsons" it's a sly Pacific Northwest reference - Moses Lake is a town in central Washington.
Odd choice of photo today. Enjoyable puzzle.  I was awaiting BYD (Chinese Auto Manufacturer), but I guess sometimes not Y. Instead, I have the little sparrow's songs dancing around my head.

Argghh. I'm an art historian AND SPELLED 'LIN' WRONG! My only mistake.

An excellent documentary on Maya Lin and the wall, from start to finish and including controversies: "Maya Lin: A Strong Clear Vision."

1994 Oscar, best documentary, and very easy to come by.

Happily, the vast majority of people who matter most have great respect for her creation: Vietnam Vets.

I did Plus Two in about 15 minutes; not sure why it fell together so quickly.

By the time I came to the blog for Mashed p's, I had all but 15, 19, 20. PARROTED PREDATOR would have evolved if I had a clue like "the opposite of prey" rather than an answer for #15 ; I had PRETTINESS, but did not have the PERSISTENT anagram; it would have taken me a long time to get PEDESTRIAN PEDANTRIES for #20. A good clue might have been to separate the mundane from the complaints from a nit-picker.

I have been managing the second Sunday puzzle on my own for a while, but gave in when I could not get the last three mashed p's.

My Advice on visiting Rome:
1. Watch "Roman Holiday" with Gregory Peck, Audrey Hepburn and a very young Eddie Albert before you go.
2. Go to Trastevere at least one night for the evening Passeggiata; it happens around the Piazza of the Church of Santa Maria (which also shouldn't be missed for the mosaics).
3. When the hot and crowded of the Old City starts to weigh, spend a couple hours biking on the splendid countryside of the Appian Way. (Metro to Colli Albani, bus #660 to end of the line. Bike rentals right at the stop at a nice outdoor cafe).
4. Some evening, walk or take the bus up to the Giancolo, the highest park in Rome with beautiful views over Old City and back to St. Peters. (Don't miss the statute of Garibaldi's wife!).
See photos beginning at: http://www.flickr.com/photos/zilavy/sets/72157622422839305/.
STAIN -- #12 on the plus 2.  We have everything done and just can't get this one.

Expat 22, you are just way off on these.  I've tried #1 and #3 and not been able to figure them out within about a half hour of trying.  But I'm not going to pretend I did figure them out and throw out random guesses dressed up as answers.  If you can't get it, you can't get it.
